newsitem.title: USA: CBOT soy products end mostly higher on demand.
newsitem.headline: CBOT soy products end mostly higher on demand.

text.p: Talk of strong demand for soyoil and soymeal, especially by China, plus a late rally in soybeans boosted CBOT soy product futures to a mostly higher close, traders said.
The market continued to hear rumblings of Chinese demand for soybeans, soyoil and soymeal and commercial bull spreading helped magnify the talk, they said.

The October oil and meal contract expired quietly at 1201 CDT. October soymeal closed at $231.00 per ton, up $1.30 per ton and October soyoil went off the board at 22.75 cent per lb, down 0.16 per lb.
Traders said the soy complex was boosted late by rain-delayed harvesting of the U.S. soybean crop, slow farmer selling, firm cash basis markets and the China talk.
Soyoil futures volume was estimated at 14,000, down from 14,921 Monday, according to the CBOT. Soymeal futures volume was estimated at 24,000, down from 26,173 Monday.
Soyoil closed 0.05 to 0.17 cent per lb higher, with December up 0.10 at 23.31. Soymeal was $3.40 per ton higher to $1.20 lower, with December up $3.40 at $225.20.
